meta.title: The American Revolution
meta.description: The birth of a nation and its alternative paths to independence
meta.historical_context: The American Revolution transformed thirteen British colonies into an independent nation. The conflict tested revolutionary ideals against military reality, with victory far from certain at many critical junctures.
meta.divergence_point: Critical decisions during the Revolutionary War that could have changed the outcome

george_washington.name: George Washington
george_washington.description: The indispensable man whose leadership held the revolutionary cause together through its darkest hours.

benjamin_franklin.name: Benjamin Franklin
benjamin_franklin.description: The sage whose diplomacy secured crucial French support for the revolutionary cause.

king_george_iii.name: King George III
king_george_iii.description: The king whose stubbornness prolonged the war but whose flexibility could have prevented it.

british_victory.title: The Loyalist States: British Victory
british_victory.description: What if Washington was captured at Valley Forge and the revolution collapsed?
british_victory.divergence_description: British forces launch a surprise winter attack on Valley Forge, capturing Washington and destroying the Continental Army.

valley_forge_disaster_1778.title: The Valley Forge Catastrophe
valley_forge_disaster_1778.description: British intelligence discovers the weakness of the Continental Army's winter position. A coordinated assault captures Washington and scatters his forces.
valley_forge_disaster_1778.impact: The revolutionary cause loses its symbol of unity. Colonial resistance fragments into guerrilla warfare.

reconciliation_act_1780.title: The Reconciliation Act
reconciliation_act_1780.description: Britain offers amnesty and limited self-governance to colonies that lay down arms. Most accept, fearing further bloodshed.
reconciliation_act_1780.impact: The thirteen colonies remain British, gaining parliamentary representation but not independence.

loyalist_dominance_1790.title: The Loyalist Ascendancy
loyalist_dominance_1790.description: Former loyalists dominate colonial governments. Revolutionary sympathizers emigrate to French Louisiana or Spanish Florida.
loyalist_dominance_1790.impact: North America develops differently, with closer ties to the British Empire.

consequences.short_term: Revolutionary ideals are suppressed but not extinguished. Underground resistance continues.
consequences.long_term: No American Revolution inspires French and Latin American independence movements less effectively.
consequences.global_impact: The British Empire remains stronger into the 20th century. Democracy spreads more slowly worldwide.

british_victory.present_day_status: The Commonwealth of American States remains part of a constitutional British Empire. Independence came gradually through negotiation in the 1920s. North America is more culturally British, with stronger monarchist traditions.

early_independence.title: The Olive Branch Accepted: Peaceful Resolution
early_independence.description: What if King George III accepted the Olive Branch Petition in 1775?
early_independence.divergence_description: Parliament moderates convince the King to accept colonial demands for representation without taxation.

olive_branch_accepted_1775.title: The Royal Compromise
olive_branch_accepted_1775.description: King George III, swayed by moderate advisors, accepts the Olive Branch Petition and suspends the Intolerable Acts.
olive_branch_accepted_1775.impact: Armed conflict is averted. Negotiations begin for colonial representation in Parliament.

imperial_parliament_1780.title: The Imperial Parliament Act
imperial_parliament_1780.description: A reformed Parliament includes representatives from all colonies, creating a true trans-Atlantic legislature.
imperial_parliament_1780.impact: The British Empire becomes the world's first transcontinental democracy.

peaceful_evolution_1800.title: Dominion Status Achieved
peaceful_evolution_1800.description: The American colonies achieve dominion status, gaining autonomy while maintaining ties to Britain.
peaceful_evolution_1800.impact: A peaceful model for decolonization emerges a century early.

consequences.short_term: Revolutionary sentiment channels into reformist politics rather than armed rebellion.
consequences.long_term: A united Anglo-American Empire dominates the 19th century economically and militarily.
consequences.global_impact: Democratic ideals spread through reform rather than revolution. Less violent path to independence for other colonies.

early_independence.present_day_status: The American Dominion remains Britain's closest ally in a reformed Commonwealth. The special relationship is literal political union. English-speaking democracies form an even more dominant global bloc.

fragmented_states.title: The Disunited States: Failed Federation
fragmented_states.description: What if the Constitutional Convention of 1787 failed and the states went separate ways?
fragmented_states.divergence_description: Deep divisions over slavery, trade, and state sovereignty cause the Constitutional Convention to collapse.

convention_failure_1787.title: The Philadelphia Breakdown
convention_failure_1787.description: Irreconcilable differences between northern and southern states doom the Constitutional Convention. Delegates return home in bitter failure.
convention_failure_1787.impact: The Articles of Confederation collapse. States begin acting as independent nations.

trade_wars_1790.title: The Tariff Wars
trade_wars_1790.description: States impose tariffs on each other. New York and Pennsylvania nearly go to war over river navigation rights.
trade_wars_1790.impact: Economic fragmentation weakens all former colonies. European powers exploit divisions.

regional_blocs_1800.title: The Three Americas
regional_blocs_1800.description: Three regional confederations emerge: New England Federation, Mid-Atlantic Alliance, and Southern Confederacy.
regional_blocs_1800.impact: North America fragments like South America did in our timeline.

consequences.short_term: Economic depression and interstate conflict weaken all regions.
consequences.long_term: No united America means no westward expansion. European powers maintain control of western territories.
consequences.global_impact: No American superpower in the 20th century. Britain and France dominate longer. Different World War outcomes.

fragmented_states.present_day_status: North America is divided into seven independent nations: New England, New York Republic, Pennsylvania Commonwealth, Virginia Union, Carolina Federation, Georgia and the Gulf States. Constant rivalries prevent unification. British Canada is the dominant North American power.
